Quantum theory is a mathematical structure that is widely accepted as a model of the physical world. However, the mathematical structure is not self-evident, and there are many different ways to define it. This paper provides a definition that is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. The definition is based on a set of axioms that are satisfied by the category of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This definition of quantum theory is a step toward a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is independent of any particular formalism.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian species, and we show that the myxozoan body plan is remarkably reduced compared with that of cnidarians. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism and the origin of the Myxozoa. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused a global health crisis and has led to a significant economic and social impact. The SARS-CoV-2 virus is able to evade the host immune response by blocking the nuclear import of transcription factors that are essential for the induction of antiviral genes. In this study, we show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear import of transcription factors and, as a consequence, to impair the expression of antiviral genes. Our results unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the channel. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on the channel: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the channel, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the channel. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this population growth. This study shows that the variability of maize production will increase substantially in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries as the Earth’s climate continues to warm. This variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports. This will increase the risk of food price spikes, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savannas. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the diet of large herbivores. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and digestive physiology, some species were almost-exclusive grazers, whereas others were almost-exclusive browsers. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that large herbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is expected to vary widely, and many businesses expect to remain open for a long time. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the CARES Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern for the marine environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still debated. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The age of the Solar System is one of the most important and fundamental facts in astronomy. It is also one of the most difficult to determine. We present a method to determine the age of the Solar System based on the cosmogenic nuclide 21Ne. The method is based on the fact that the production of 21Ne in the interstellar medium is proportional to the cosmic ray exposure of the grains from which the Ne-21 is produced.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased by a factor of 10. The effective catch per unit of effort (CPUE) has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to the mother during pregnancy correlates with an increase in reproductive output. We show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in the number of offspring, but rather an increase in the size of the offspring.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be achieved by limiting the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in the brain. This would have important implications for the treatment of synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controlling blood pressure, and controlling inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control its function in response to a wide variety of stimuli. The endothelium is able to integrate multiple lines of information from multiple sources and coordinate its responses. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelium is a highly connected network of cells with short path lengths and a power-law degree distribution. The network is effective for both local and global communication and is able to rapidly and robustly respond to stimuli. The findings have implications for understanding the structure and function of the endothelium and for the development of new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and open data has never been greater. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance systems. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers, epidemiologists, and policy makers in their efforts to understand and respond to the pandemic.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The selectivity filter is also the site of the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the inactivation gate. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is not fully understood. One of the most important aspects of the gut microbiome is the diversity of microorganisms that inhabit the gut. This diversity is important for the health of the host, as it provides redundancy in the case of a single species being lost. The diversity of microorganisms also provides a defense against pathogens, as they are not all susceptible to the same pathogens. The diversity of microorganisms in the gut is also important for the health of the microorganisms, as they need to be able to compete with each other for resources. This study shows that one of the microorganisms that inhabit the gut is able to synthesize natural products that can be used as a defense against other microorganisms.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical devices with desired behaviors is a critical issue for the development of smart and intelligent machines. However, the design of a single device with a specific behavior is challenging, let alone the design of a large number of devices with different behaviors. Here, we present a design strategy to synthesize mechanical devices with arbitrary behaviors. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The synthesized structures are digitally designed and then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The structures are then assembled into architectures to enhance programmability. The proposed strategy can be extended to design mechanical devices with complex behaviors and is expected to be widely applicable to the design of mechanical devices with specific behaviors for a wide range of applications.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. One of the major challenges in cancer treatment is the resistance of cancer cells to the cytotoxic effects of chemotherapy. In this study, we show that the inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In conclusion, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. This study provides a new strategy for cancer treatment. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. Here, we show that these drugs act on the Ca2+ signaling machinery and promote vascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Instead, the policy failed to protect these species, and the population declines accelerated. We also show that the policy was successful in halting the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train the network with a large number of training samples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of trainable parameters, and that is easy to train and apply. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices, such as computers and smartphones, has increased dramatically in the past decade. This study shows that the use of such devices in the hours before bedtime has a negative impact on sleep. In particular, the use of electronic devices suppresses melatonin, which is important for sleep onset and quality. The use of electronic devices also has a negative impact on the timing of the circadian clock, which is important for alertness and performance.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth system. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites is consistent with terrestrial sources, and the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results suggest that the YDB cooling was triggered by an impact event in the vicinity of the Quebecia terrain.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell responses, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice results in a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. Moreover, we show that the development of autoimmunity is not only dependent on the type of antigen, but also on the stage of the immune response.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of beetles and the factors that drove their diversification remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our results show that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of the plant kingdom, and that the evolution of herbivory was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the design of social systems.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is about 1,700 km in radius and has a density of 12.0–12.5 g/cm3. It is the only solid core in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more likely than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and the solidification of the core–mantle boundary region. They also provide a new approach to understanding the formation of other solid cores in the solar system.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced reactivity to DA stimulation is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the uniquely human ability that has shaped our species and our planet. Yet, despite its importance, the language-processing mechanisms in the human brain are only just beginning to be understood. Here, we show that artificial neural networks trained on large datasets of brain activity predict brain and behavior in humans while decoding the next word in a sentence. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that we may be able to decode the meaning of a person’s brain signals while they are speaking—a potentially transformative capability for neuroscience, psychiatry, and psychology.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is not clear whether the success of DL is due to the success of the algorithms or the success of the models. In this paper, we show that the success of DL is due to the success of the models. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. These results imply a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the success of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major challenge for the world. It is also a major challenge for science. The pandemic’s origin, spread, and severity are hotly debated, and the scientific community is currently engaged in a vigorous discussion about the role of the media. In this context, it is important to critically assess the role of psychology in the pandemic’s management. This article discusses the role of a classic psychological experiment in the spread of COVID-19 and its impact on the public.

Leprosy is a disease that has plagued humanity for thousands of years. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the cause of a reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon, which is associated with an uncultured pathogen, has remained a mystery. Here, we report the genome sequence of the Lucio’s phenomenon pathogen, M. lepromatosis, and show that it is closely related to M. leprae, despite having diverged from it approximately 14 million years ago. This finding suggests that the two pathogens have retained many of the same functions, and may still cause disease in humans. This work also provides a framework for the study of ancient pathogens, and may lead to the discovery of new ones. (Less)

The evolution of entanglement is a key question in the study of quantum many-body systems. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit to study the evolution of entanglement in quantum quenches. Our result is based on the integrability of the one-dimensional Heisenberg model, which allows us to compute the entanglement entropy of the steady state and its excitations. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg XXZ chain. Our result provides a general framework to study the entanglement dynamics in integrable models and, in particular, to study the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. This work is a step toward the understanding of the evolution of entanglement in generic quantum many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health crisis that has affected millions of people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to end the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate is protective in hamsters, and the data support its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This vaccine candidate is a promising candidate for the fight against COVID-19. The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which was able to fit mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a Bayesian approach to model outbreaks, which allows for the inclusion of many data points and the consideration of uncertainty. This approach is particularly important for outbreaks that occurred a long time ago, when data are scarce. Finally, our results suggest that plague was a major threat to human health in Europe for centuries.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic of debate in the field of comparative cognition. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of animals. We also show that the evolution of brain structure is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of animals.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton. It is thought to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not known. Here, we show that the action of ADF is strongly influenced by the mechanical state of the filament network. We find that the presence of a mechanical torque enhances severing of cross-linked filaments, and that this effect is critical to the ability of ADF to sever highly connected filament networks. Our results suggest that the presence of mechanical torque is a key factor in the action of ADF.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, the sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of fructose versus glucose are unclear. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is also a unique case study for the settlement of an island, as it is geographically far from the main landmasses. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we show that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a few centuries, and that the settlement was not a homogeneous process. In addition, we show that the settlement was not a homogeneous process, as the genetic diversity is not only influenced by the admixture, but also by the geography.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. The results suggest that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. The findings have implications for the design of social networks and for the study of emotional contagion in the real world. They also suggest that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The ribosome is the central protein-synthesizing machine in the cell, and the mRNA sequences that direct translation are encoded in the messenger RNA (mRNA). In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can have a profound impact on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ can promote the low-level synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the reconstituted translation system as well as human cells, and increases the rate of near-cognate Val-tRNAVal reacting on a ΨUU codon. The vast majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions, and our study suggests that one consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ can be to modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for the translation of other mRNA modifications and for the interpretation of mRNA sequencing data. (Less)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and quality of life. This finding has important implications for health promotion and disease prevention, as well as for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of aquatic mammals is driven toward a common size of ∼500 kg, and that this size is optimal for the aquatic environment. This result is consistent with the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven toward a common size by the energetic demands of the aquatic environment.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. Here, we show that the virus replicates more efficiently at cool temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to a wide range of environmental signals. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa detects the mechanical activity of its type IV pili, a major surface adhesin, on short timescales. This mechanosensory system is required for the regulation of type IV pili activity, which in turn is required for the detection of surfaces. Our results thus support a mechanochemical model where a chemosensory system measures the mechanically induced conformational changes in stretched type IV pili. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa not only uses type IV pili for surface-specific twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria sense and respond to mechanical signals and may have implications for the development of antimicrobial therapies. The use of pesticides in agriculture is increasing worldwide, and the number of pesticides is growing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, including the presence of pesticides in surface water, the stringency of environmental regulations, and the effects of pesticides on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is widespread and that the concentrations of pesticides in water are often high enough to cause harm to aquatic organisms. The results of this study suggest that the current environmental regulations are not sufficient to protect surface water from the effects of pesticides.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including wildlife, and the potential for spillback to humans is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is common in many regions of the United States. We also show that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and suggest that a “One Health” approach is needed to monitor and mitigate the spread of SARS-CoV-2 in wildlife. Our study highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2 in animals. This knowledge is critical for the development of effective strategies to mitigate the risk of spillback to humans.
The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. The paper examines the problems and proposes solutions.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques, which are not present in all animal models of the disease. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species, which are the most toxic form of the protein, are the primary cause of the early inflammatory response in AD. We also demonstrate that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a major source of proinflammatory factors, which may trigger the immune response in neighboring cells and regions of the brain. These findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus) is one of the most important events in the history of agriculture. The earliest evidence for the domestication of the chicken comes from the archaeological site of Catalhoyuk, Turkey, and dates to the third millennium B.C.E. However, the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. Our results show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread in the Southern Levant as early as the fourth century B.C.E. and that the earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not known how many distinct steps are involved. This study shows that the maltose binding protein, a large protein, folds through distinct steps, and that the steps are not all on the same time scale. The results suggest that the folding of a protein is a multistep process.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress conditions has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not fully understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions that enable accumulation of Np4. We also show that the decapping activity of ApaH is replaced by a different enzyme, RppH, in cells experiencing stress. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. Consequently, a second RppH-catalyzed deprotection step is required to produce the monophosphorylated 5′ terminus needed to stimulate rapid RNA degradation.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main goal of treatment is to restore immune function. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline, an amino acid that is derived from arginine, is more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves with a constant rate of change, and in which the system’s state fluctuates about a critical value. SOC is observed in a wide variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, fire spreading, neural networks, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and sensors. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its mechanical properties are easily damaged. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This work provides a new route to control the electronic and mechanical properties of diamond, and it is expected to open up new avenues for the development of diamond-based devices.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. Here, we report the solution structure of a unique peptide, NCR044, which is expressed in nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula and exhibits antifungal activity. The structure of the peptide is largely disordered and highly dynamic, with one four-residue α-helix and one three-residue antiparallel β-sheet stabilized by two disulfide bonds. The peptide also exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It inhibited germination in quiescent spores of B. cinerea. In germlings, it breached the fungal plasma membrane and induced reactive oxygen species. It bound to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. Time-lapse confocal and superresolution microscopy revealed strong fungal cell wall binding, penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. Our work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular mechanisms of intersexual continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the Drosophila sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a key component of the blood clotting system. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and that the binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We also show that force application switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This explains the pathophysiology of VWD mutations. The conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the A1 domain is a simple, single-domain receptor. These results are important for understanding the role of force in the regulation of other receptors. They also provide a model for the regulation of other receptors by force. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the role of viruses in the human body has only recently been recognized. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and it provides a resource for future research.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the observational capability is inadequate. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The observations show that the increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the surface is inferred from the isotopic compositions of marine cherts, but this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous and cardiovascular systems. Ion channels are also important for the pathophysiology of cardiac arrhythmias. Ion channels are also important for the normal function of the immune system. Ion channels are also important for the pathophysiology of autoimmune diseases. Ion channels are also important for the normal function of the endocrine system. Ion channels are also important for the pathophysiology of diabetes. Ion channels are also important for the normal function of the reproductive system. Ion channels are also important for the pathophysiology of infertility.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with an estimated 207 million cases and 627,000 deaths in 2019. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite uses a single protein, erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175), to bind to glycophorin A (GPA) on the surface of the RBC. We show that this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting that it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and could lead to the development of new antimalarial strategies.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and sensors. However, it is not a perfect material, and its properties can be improved by engineering its structure. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely closed, by applying a small strain. This finding opens up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be opened, by applying a large strain. This finding can be used to control the phase transition from diamond to graphite. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have important implications for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection in low humidity environments. This article is protected by copyright. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence, from the beginning to the end, word by word. However, whether this structure is actually built in this way is unknown. Here, we show that the brain builds a phrase structure, from the beginning to the end, word by word, and that this structure is compressed into a tree-like structure at the end of the sentence. This provides initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggests that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our results may help to explain the brain’s processing of language.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt pathway, which is involved in development and cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the Wnt pathway. This subtle feature may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra, and that this circuit is necessary for the eating behavior. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of this element is the main factor limiting crop yields. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing activity of bacteria in association with plants would allow for the delivery of biologically fixed nitrogen to the plant, thus increasing the efficiency of the use of this essential nutrient. Here, we describe the development of a system that allows for the control of the nitrogen-fixing activity of bacteria in association with barley plants. This system could be used to control the nitrogen-fixing activity of bacteria in the field, thus increasing the efficiency of the use of this essential nutrient. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and design of novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, thus suggesting that the latter can be moderated to 0.36(±0.06) °C by reducing tropospheric ozone and methane.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on global health and the economy. The development of vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic. We report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 receptor-binding domain (RBD) variant that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing and elicits a strong immune response. This variant is expected to be a component of many of the vaccines currently in development and may be used in combination with other vaccines.

The development of neural crest-derived tissues is a complex process involving multiple signaling pathways. Here, we show that the zebrafish homolog of the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene, drALK, is involved in the regulation of neural crest development. We demonstrate that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, drALKals, is able to activate the zebrafish homolog of ALK, drLtk, in vitro and in vivo. Furthermore, we show that the loss of function of drALKals leads to a complete loss of iridophores in zebrafish larvae. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKals in neural crest development. This is an important step toward understanding the role of ALK/ALKals in human neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a well-documented event, but the details of its early evolution are still largely unknown. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age in Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during this critical period of development. Our results suggest that the plague lineage that gave rise to the disease we know today was not a single, stable lineage, but rather a mosaic of lineages that diversified over time. This is also the first time that the flea-adapted form of plague has been identified in the Bronze Age, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its relationship to its vector, the flea. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. The management of agricultural systems can affect the amount of carbon (C) stored in the soil. This study shows that the management of annual cropping systems on a Midwestern Mollisol can increase the amount of C stored in the soil. The management practices that increased the amount of C stored in the soil were reduced tillage, a diversified crop rotation with cover crops and legumes, and the application of manure. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses from wildlife to humans. We present a framework for identifying and prioritizing wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to cause epidemics and pandemics. We also present a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and to prioritize research and surveillance efforts. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We demonstrate that nesocodin is attractive to the vertebrate pollinator Phelsuma geckos, and that this alkaloid is also present in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work provides a chemical basis for the evolution of a key trait that is essential for plant reproduction.

The history of Europe is marked by a complex interplay of demographic processes, including waves of immigration from outside the continent. However, the genetic history of Europe during the period of cultural change is largely unknown. Here, we present a genome-wide analysis of a panel of functional variants and a large number of genomes from the late 5th/early 6th century AD, which provides insights into the genetic history of Europe during this period. Our results indicate that women, in particular, had a high genetic diversity, which was reflected in the genetic ancestry of the individuals. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide insights into the history of Europe during the period of cultural change and the impact of female migration on the genetic history of Europe.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, are investigated. The results show that the receptor usage of the two bat coronaviruses is opposite to each other, and that the host cellular proteases are also a determinant of host range. These findings suggest that the capability of the two bat coronaviruses to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission is possible.

The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to that of S. cerevisiae. However, the stability of the replicative pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study also provides a unique system to study the dynamics of the pol δ holoenzyme and the role of PCNA in DNA replication.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In this paper, we describe the construction of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. This polymerase is able to replicate RNA, amplify RNA, and synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Thus, the polymerase can replicate genetic information and convert it into functional molecules, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with economic and demographic factors. These correlations are consistent with three classical theories of urban change: the “human capital” theory, the “tipping” theory, and the “invasion” theory. Our results suggest that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are important determinants of neighborhood change and that physical improvements are more likely to occur in neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults, that are more attractive to start with, and that are more likely to be near the central business district and other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results also suggest that physical improvements are more likely to occur in areas that are already improving.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a metal that can be toxic to cells. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the existence of copper-binding natural products in fungi is not. Here we report the discovery of a copper-binding natural product, xanthocillin, in Aspergillus fumigatus. Xanthocillin is secreted and has antimicrobial properties, and it is copper dependent. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for this class of natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This discovery has implications for the role of copper in fungal biology and for the development of antifungal therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, is a rare mineral on Earth and on Mars. It is a product of high-temperature, high-pressure, and high-temperature (HTHHT) conditions, and is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of tridymite in a laminated mudstone at the base of a crater wall/rim/central peak suggests that the sediment source region was a HTHHT environment. The presence of a HTHHT environment and the cogenetic nature of the tridymite, feldspar, and glass suggest that the sediment source region was a HTHHT environment. Frost is one of the most common abiotic stressors of plants and animals, and the timing of spring frosts is a key determinant of their impact. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is already affecting the performance of trees in Europe and Asia. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk, and can inform the development of insurance policies for agriculture and forestry.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, Th17 cells can give rise to two distinct subsets, one of which retains an IL-17A+ phenotype and is responsible for the induction of colitis, whereas the other, which is deficient in IFN-γ, is responsible for the development of classic Th1 cells. We show that the development of colitis requires the dual transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells and the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms. This work also suggests that the development of Th1 cells may be dependent on the presence of Th17 cells.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is difficult to model in animal models, and there are no effective treatments. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the development of new treatments for ALS.

The role of the microbiome in vector competence for infectious agents is a topic of great interest. Here, we show that the human granulocytic anaplasmosis pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, modifies the microbiota of the vector, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the vector. We show that the pathogen induces the vector to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These data provide a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will be useful for the development of vector control strategies for vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short-tailed bird group is a major group in the evolution of the avian tail, and the study of this group is important for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, and provide evidence for the mosaic evolution of the avian tail.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for camouflage, communication, and other functions. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during the evolution of vertebrates. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most diverse group of protease inhibitors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The ability of breast cancer cells to form cancer stem cells (CSCs) is a major obstacle to treatment. CSCs are responsible for tumor initiation and relapse, and are resistant to chemotherapy. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the ALKBH5 m6A demethylase, which increases the expression of pluripotency factors and the CSC phenotype. These findings suggest that ALKBH5 could be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. This paper describes a method to determine the animal origin of parchment, which is important for the study of the history of the Bible and codicology.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery based on the age of the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the boundary at Meishan, China. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the regulation of various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we report the generation of intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system of the host and for the development of vaccines and antibodies. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2, and we have compared the structure of the spike in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the mutant virus. (Read more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even in the case of a single player. The result is also new even in the case of a single player when the action sets are infinite. The result is new even in the case of a single player when the action sets are countable and the payoffs are Borel-measurable.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites.
