The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and biology. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. Furthermore, we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is of general interest to chemists and physicists.

We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the main driver of changes in global fire activity over the past century. This has led to a reduction in fire activity, which has the potential to offset some of the warming caused by human activities. However, the effect is not universal, and the risk of more extreme fires is also present. Our results highlight the importance of human demography in shaping the future of fire regimes and the climate–fire–carbon cycle system.

The mutualism between animals and their symbiotic microbes is one of the most important relationships in nature. However, the mechanisms that regulate the stability of these associations are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan by the host animal is sufficient to maintain the stability of the symbiotic relationship between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the metabolic products to enhance the level of oxygen available to the symbiont in its habitat. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis stability, and it may also have implications for the evolution of symbiosis.

The study of text data is a major challenge in the social sciences. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning and capitalizes on their distinct capabilities. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to a wide range of domains, from social media to medical records. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for more than four centuries. This event is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium, after which it established itself in European rodents. We show that this event was preceded by repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors, which were likely caused by climate-driven changes in the abundance of rodent reservoirs in Asia. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of a series of introductions, rather than a single event.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of marine ecosystems. They are also a valuable resource for humans, as they contain a variety of compounds with potential industrial and pharmaceutical applications. The recent discovery of a disease affecting sea stars on the Pacific Coast of North America has led to a mass mortality event, with the loss of at least 20 species. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is highly contagious. The virus is likely to have a negative impact on the ecosystem and on the economic value of the affected species.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, allowing us to study the distribution of African and Asian ancestry, as well as the demographic history of the island. We find that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed, and that the settlement was not homogeneous across the island. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the human history of Madagascar, and may help to understand the settlement history of other islands.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their assessments are critical for monitoring crop conditions and making timely decisions. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily integrated into quantitative models. We show that the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition survey, which has been collecting crop assessments for over 30 y, can be used to construct a continuous probabilistic measure of crop status. This allows us to monitor crop conditions with unprecedented accuracy and to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of harnessing the power of “people as sensors” to improve agricultural monitoring and management.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of individual neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can support memory, but that changes in the intrinsic excitability of neurons is a more general mechanism that can support memory on a variety of timescales. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear, with some studies finding increases in soil respiration with warming and others finding no change. Here, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, and we find that soil respiration does not increase with warming in all biomes. Moreover, we find that soil respiration in colder climates is more responsive to warming than soil respiration in warmer climates. These findings provide a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. We discuss the implications of our findings for our understanding of the response of soil respiration to climate change. (Abridged)

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of life on Earth. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of plants, and the molecular signature of this transition is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome, and that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the plastid genome. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water availability in South Africa. We show that the probability of such a drought will increase by a factor of five to six by the year 2100 under a medium-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to eight times under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also show that the probability of such a drought will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under SSP2-4.5. This study provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the role of human-induced climate change in the recent drought in SSA. However, the results are limited to the region of interest and should be extended to other parts of the world. This will be the focus of future work.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” has been hailed as a “second discovery of the century” after the discovery of the structure of DNA. The discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, in the red trinitite, is a reminder that the search for new materials continues to this day.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy that drives the biosphere. The core of this process is the capture of solar radiation by the chlorophyll pigments. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key feature of the chlorophyll pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one from bacteria and one from plants and cyanobacteria. The function of the plant and cyanobacterial enzyme has remained a mystery, until now.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the progression of Alzheimer’s disease. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we focused on a specific kinase, neuroprotective kinase 1 (ASK1), and its role in neuroinflammation. We found that ASK1 is required for microglia-mediated neuroinflammation, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia exacerbates the disease. We also found that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of EAE, suggesting a phase-specific role of ASK1 in glial cells. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia and astrocytes plays a major role in the development of neuroinflammation, and ASK1 inhibitors may be a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased in recent decades, and that this increase is very likely due to human-caused climate change. This finding has important implications for water resources management, ecosystem health, and fire risk in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing new therapeutic approaches. It also provides a model system for studying the molecular mechanisms of behavioral flexibility. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is a cross-national replication of a 2015 study that found that people react more strongly to negative than positive information. The current work extends the study to 17 countries, 6 continents, and 10,000 participants. It also examines the relationship between individual differences in negativity bias and the content of news consumption. The results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive information. They also show that individual differences in negativity bias are related to the type of news content that people consume. These findings have implications for the study of the psychology of news consumption, and for the design of news content.

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) (SO(2)) channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling and homeostasis. Mutations in the pore-forming protein of the SO(2) channel, ORAI1, or in the Ca2+ sensor, STIM1, result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy, and in ORAI1, associated with a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities and nonprogressive myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO(2) channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO(2) channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates by neurons, and that this process is dependent on the activity of the endocytic machinery. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spread of aggregates can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis in the spreading neurons. These results suggest that the spread of aggregates is a key element of neurodegenerative disease, and that the use of Drosophila as a model system can be used to study the mechanisms underlying this process.

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, which we named Myotis pilosus protein (MP), inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MP-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats. (PsycINFO Database Record

The one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth, and is provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the enzyme is a promising target for cancer therapy. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that this effect is reversed by SHMT enzymatic activity. Finally, we show that formate is a potent inhibitor of lymphoma, and that this effect is reversed by SHMT enzymatic activity. Thus, formate is a targetable metabolic deficiency of lymphoma. These findings provide a foundation for the development of a therapeutic strategy for lymphoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a unifying hypothesis for the pathogenesis of ALS, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The Cretaceous is a key time in the evolution of plants, including the origin of the flowering plants. The study of the aquatic plants of this period is of great interest because of the possible role that aquatic habitats may have played in the early evolution of the flowering plants. The study of the aquatic plant Montsechia, first described more than 100 y ago, is presented here. The study of Montsechia, together with the study of other aquatic plants of the Cretaceous, may help to understand the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral sequences. Here we present 10 ancient viral genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that viruses have been infecting humans for a long time and that the human–virus relationship has been evolving over time. This study also shows that the human–virus relationship has been evolving over time.

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models. This finding is important because it implies that climate models are capturing the key processes that control the rate of sea level rise.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. Thus, the gap in pain between the more and less educated has widened in each successive birth cohort. The increase seen across birth cohorts cannot be explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity for the less educated, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach is able to identify the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. The detailed picture of structure and reactivity that emerges from this work highlights the fate of the L-serine hydroxyl leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work also provides a detailed description of the isostere benzimidazole, showing why it does not react, while indole does. These results are expected to be of interest to enzymologists and structural biologists, as well as to those interested in the chemistry of the active site.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the available treatment options are limited. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of a rapid and effective vaccine development. The data presented here may also be used to assess the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a clinical trial for the treatment of COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. The mutualism between animals and their symbiotic microbes is one of the most important and widespread relationships in nature. However, the mechanisms that regulate the stability of these associations are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan by the host animal is sufficient to maintain the stability of the symbiotic relationship between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the metabolic products to enhance the level of oxygen available to the symbiont in its habitat. This study provides a mechanistic link between the provision of nutrients by the host and the stability of the symbiosis. It also suggests that other hosts may regulate the activities of their associated microbes through the strategic provision of specific nutrients. This study may therefore have broader implications for our understanding of the ecology of mutualistic relationships. (Less)

This paper describes a series of experiments and field studies that show that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can have a large impact on students’ behavior and well-being. The findings have implications for the future of American schools, and for the future of American society.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on transcriptional fidelity. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this system, and it is therefore important to understand how to change these choices. This study shows that it is possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a cafeteria by 60% without a significant impact on overall meal sales. This suggests that it may be possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets at the population level. The study also shows that it is possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a cafeteria by 79% without a significant impact on meat meal sales. This suggests that it may be possible to nudge people away from meat consumption. These results have important implications for the design of interventions to promote more sustainable diets.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work also provides a proof of principle for the application of AI-ETD for glycoproteomics. This method is expected to be broadly applicable to other systems. In response to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus responsible, SARS-CoV-2, has been shown to have a number of unique features that may contribute to its rapid spread and severity. One such feature is the accessory protein ORF8, which has been shown to be able to suppress the immune system. The structure of ORF8 provides insight into how this protein may be able to evade the immune system and may also provide a target for therapeutics.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. We also show that CRF acts on the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in cortical astrocytes to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, leading to an up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression and cerebral edema. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of this condition. The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The key idea is that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This is because we have “cherry picked” the data, searching for the strongest associations. We show how this idea can be formalized and used to make more powerful and principled inferences.

The development of vascular networks is a key step in the regeneration of organs. In this study, we demonstrate that the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the formation of vascular networks from human fibroblasts. This study provides a new approach for the generation of vascular networks, which can be applied to the regeneration of organs. Furthermore, the generation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study also provides a new strategy for the treatment of ischemic disorders. These findings may lead to the development of new therapies for ischemic disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the oncogenic receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened a new field of research in the field of RTKs. Here, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that the ligands augment-α1, augment-α2, and augment-β are essential for the development of iridophores, a type of photoreceptor that is present in the eye and the skin. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a new perspective on the role of RTKs in development and disease.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular basis of T2D is complex, it is well known that insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated for T2D. Herein, we show that the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. We also establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of T2D and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and cause occasional severe pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging of the viral genome is a fundamental process in all viruses, but the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular details of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This knowledge will be important for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral drugs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including hemodynamic environment. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. En face analysis of mouse arteries demonstrated an increased nuclear localization of YAP/TAZ and elevated levels of the target genes in the endothelium in atheroprone areas compared with athero-protective areas. YAP/TAZ knockdown significantly attenuated the disturbed flow

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate the geographic and seasonal extent of human-started wildfires relative to lightning-started wildfires and find that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are widely used in pest control. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we report the identification of a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has recently emerged as a cause of severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The virus replicates rapidly in the blood of infected individuals, and the time between infection and the production of infectious virus is short. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load by ∼2 d, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can help guide the development of treatment strategies for ZIKV infection. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral reefs are among the most valuable and diverse ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe impacts is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is triggered by heat stress. We show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis, and that the host’s energy demand is increased during heat stress. This leads to the catabolism of amino acids, which in turn promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients and immune responses. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of intestinal tumors. They may also provide a new perspective on the role of the microbiome in cancer and aging.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Furthermore, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation is still a matter of debate. Here, we show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a single series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis highlights the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management efforts to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅

The ability to regenerate is a defining characteristic of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost, and the few remaining neurons that can regenerate are unable to do so effectively. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens the door to a new platform for discovery of factors that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences during the process of DNA replication. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and the survival of species. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we show that the pattern of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we show that the dominant component of this fluctuation is topographically similar to the default mode network (DMN), a network of low-activity regions that is thought to be inactive during conscious rest. In Parkinson’s disease, the DMN-like component of the resting brain was subordinated to a disease-related pattern, and this was associated with reduced deactivation of the DMN during task performance. In Alzheimer’s disease, the DMN was already reduced at diagnosis, and this was associated with reduced deactivation of the DMN during task performance. These results provide a direct link between the resting brain and its functional properties, and they have implications for the diagnosis and treatment of neurological and psychiatric disorders.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. Here we show that the yeast genome contains a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We show that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery has implications for the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes. It also has implications for the origin of the 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and that these differences are maintained in blood monocytes during the long-term follow-up of the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease, which is difficult to treat. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of many plant species, and the production of nitrogenous volatiles is particularly important for fruit aroma. However, the biosynthesis of these compounds is not well understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the precursors of these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of these important fruit aroma compounds. It also provides a model for the biosynthesis of other nitrogenous compounds in plants. (Read more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature change is one of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. We show that the additional impacts of warming are likely to be more severe than the impacts of biodiversity loss alone. Our results also highlight the importance of species’ thermal tolerance traits in determining the impacts of environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is important because many species are likely to be unable to adapt to warming in the future.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to be involved in different aspects of navigation. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice, and we found that grid cells, which are thought to be involved in the formation of a map of local space, are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data suggest that grid cells might form a network that is largely distinct from those of other cell types. This study provides a framework for understanding the organization of the navigation system in the brain.

Dodder is a root- and leafless plant that parasitizes a large number of autotrophic plant species. Dodder is able to synchronize its flowering with the flowering of its host. This study shows that the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the dodder. This is an example of a unique means of flowering regulation in a parasite, which may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the dodder to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons and a reduction in the number of dopamine-producing synapses. Here, we show that the dopamine-producing neurons are also affected by a loss of the synapses that are connected to the striosomes, the parts of the dopamine-producing neurons that are closest to the cortex. We also show that the dopamine-producing neurons are affected by a loss of the synapses that are connected to the striosomes, the parts of the dopamine-producing neurons that are closest to the cortex.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated the felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for generating the heartbeat. The SAN is composed of specialized cells, called sinoatrial cells (SACS), which are responsible for generating the electrical signal that initiates each heartbeat. The SAN is a highly specialized organelle that is responsible for generating the heartbeat, and its function is dependent on the proper functioning of its cells. Here, we report that the function of the SAN is dependent on the activity of a protein called stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1).

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore resistance has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a sustainable strategy to enhance plant resistance against insect herbivores. This study also provides a better understanding of the underlying mechanisms of the interaction between Si and JA in plant defense. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in murine macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism and suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of individual neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can support memory, but that changes in the intrinsic excitability of neurons is a more general mechanism that can support memory on a variety of timescales. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenge due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules across the cell wall. We also show that the delivery of biomolecules across the cell wall can be used to deliver genes to plants. This work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

The world’s largest freshwater bodies are threatened by nutrient pollution, which can fuel harmful algal blooms and other ecological impacts. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, and that the relative importance of small tributaries increases with lake size. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries, which are often overlooked in regulatory and monitoring programs. This approach could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a large-scale steady state of the universe is biased toward rare combinations of cosmological parameters. Our results suggest that the fine-tuning of the universe may be a consequence of the thermodynamics of chemical reactions.

This study offers a mechanistic explanation for the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with an autoimmune encephalitis caused by blocking the NMDA receptor. The study also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of autoimmune encephalitis on the brain’s electrical activity.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid increase in atmospheric CO2, which is thought to be the result of human activities. However, it is not known whether the Earth system can respond to such a perturbation in a similar way. Here, we present evidence for a similar response in the past, which occurred during a glacial period.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is a promising tool for reducing deforestation, but it is not a silver bullet.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Less)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the interaction of these alleles results in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results suggest that the genetic basis of sex determination can produce a variety of phenotypes, and that the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles can result in variation in the secondary sexual characteristics of populations. These results have implications for the evolution of sex determination and sexual polymorphism.

The retina is challenged by a number of factors that can lead to the loss of photoreceptors. One of these factors is the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We show that the level of iron in the retina can influence the levels of these adducts and their photochemical reactivity.

The evolution of specialization is one of the most important processes shaping the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional adaptations that are specific to a single prey type. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is not only possible, but also linked to the evolution of morphological and functional changes in separate structures dedicated to prey capture. Our findings help to understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide insights into the evolution of specialization in other groups of animals.

The hominin hand is one of the most important fossil anatomical features for understanding the evolution of the human lineage. The study of the hominin hand is further complicated by the fact that the earliest hominin hand fossils are incomplete. We report the discovery of a hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene of Kenya that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and the hominin lineage. It also has implications for the interpretation of the hominin fossil record in the Middle Pleistocene.

The one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth, and is provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the enzyme is a promising target for cancer therapy. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cells. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import, and thus defective glycine metabolism, in these cells. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer cells. This work provides a framework for the design of cancer-specific SHMT inhibitors. It also provides a metabolic rationale for the use of formate as a cancer-specific rescue of SHMT inhibition. Finally, it provides a metabolic rationale for the use of formate as a cancer-specific rescue of SHMT inhibition.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This finding is important because it shows that, in addition to the well-known benefits of forests in terms of environmental services, they can also provide important benefits in terms of people’s diets. This study also shows that, in terms of meeting nutrition goals, it is important to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting people’s food needs. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern agriculture is a major driver of the global economy, but it is also a major contributor to soil degradation. In particular, the use of farm machinery has increased the weight of vehicles, which has led to compaction of the soil, a process that reduces the capacity of the soil to support plant growth. We show that the weight of modern farm machinery has increased the risk of subsoil compaction, which is now widespread over 20% of arable land. This risk is particularly high in soils with a high clay content, which are the most productive soils. We hypothesize that the development of subsoil compaction is a recent phenomenon, and we suggest that the large size of sauropods, the largest animals that walked Earth, may have played a role in reducing this risk.
